title: Do people take life for granted? - Quora

response.answer_text: Without a doubt, yes. When you reflect upon the universe as a whole, we’re likely one of the only living beings in existence. There’s only one chance to live life to the fullest, and I see it thrown out every single day, and I even do it myself. But that’s no excuse for me. Often times, people never really fully understand this, and so a small problem in the world we live in could appear so much worse just because of how we think in the moment. Don’t be afraid to take the chances you desperately want because you’ll never know what would’ve happened if you didn’t. We’re so scared of the “what if this happens,” that we solely think it’s our only probable outcome. How we move forward as a species on this planet is through taking the chances. Later on in life, you’ll always wonder what could’ve been, and you’ll regret not taking the chance of chasing after what you wanted. Because of the fear of judgment or way of standing out against normality, we try so hard to fit in; because us humans act on two things: acceptance, and avoidance. Yes, the road may be difficult, but focus solely on what you want to achieve, and you will inevitably get it. There will be hardships in this road, but that road will appear with whatever path you choose, so think about what type of life you really want to live. Another thing we all take for granted and never fully realize is that we do not have enough time; we never do. I learned this through my role model, who has inspired me to use every single second to the fullest. This is the true meaning of living life to the fullest; cherish the small and big things. You never know when something might just disappear in your life. Go live your life everyone. Make the time worth it because we only get the chance once.

Well, yes. The uppermost question would be why wouldn’t they? I am thinking expressly of life this minute because I am pondering your question. Last night, when my cat Owain crawled on my chest to purr and settle down I thought of his warmth, comfort, weight and sound. What I was actually doing was experiencing his life. Did I take it for granted that he had life? Yes I did. I am used to life. I see life in recognizable forms all around me. Life has recognizable seasons. I recognize death as an inevitability. I watch leaves curl and fall every year as I also watch them sprout green again. It’s when I think of my own close calls or I read or remember someone young who was lost that I sink into “life”. I miss people in my life who have died, but I am also gifted with rationality. When I was a teenager I was so objective. Death was a fallacy. We had two facile everyday expressions. They were facile because they were difficult to comprehend in reality. The expressions were.. Today is a good day to die, until I was hit by another car at 16. I was stopped at a red light so no, it wasn’t my doing. When I was taken to the hosp for emerg surgery and saw my physician dad retch when he looked at me I understood instantly that I could die. Expression hit a little close to home and it was shifted to the back burner. The other was a true facility, Life is for the living. Yes again, not clever, just sanguine. I don’t blame myself for rote observations. Until I have reason to question life, life simply, is. Life is stages not an if. IS: equal : homogeneous : uniform isentropic, isomeric, isocyanate, for or from different individuals of the same species  one winter afternoon - ee cummings one winter afternoon (at the magical hourwhen is becomes if) a bespangled clownstanding on eighth streethanded me a flower. Nobody, it’s safeto say, observed him but myself;and why? because without any doubt he waswhatever(first and last) mostpeople fear most:a mystery for which i’veno word except alive –that is,completely alertand miraculously whole; with not merely a mind and a heart but unquestionably a soul–by no means funereally hilarious (or otherwise democratic)but essentially poeticor ethereally serious: a fine not a coarse clown(no mob, but a person) and while never saying a word who was anything but dumb;since the silence of him self sang like a bird. Mostpeople have been heardscreaming for international measures that render hell rational– i thank heaven somebody’s crazy enough to give me a daisy blogspot **Disclaimer: I write in bold face type because I have Multiple Sclerosis. Poor eyesight as a result of Optic Neuritis.** It is for medical reasons.

Yes, we always see a small problem as 10 times worse then it actually is when there are people in the world who are actually suffering, real things, right now. People get mad if their phone breaks, we can still survive with or without a mobile phone. Why should we get mad at such simple things when there are people living in war zones, without sanitation and health care. The people who have it all really do take life for granted, I always say collect memories not things because when it comes down to it is your flashy car, or the latest iPhone going to really matter if it were your last few days? No the thing that would matter is having the people you love most around you, family and friend not face book and your Instagram followers.

Certainly when a person is young they certainly do. I know when I was in the age group between fourteen and twenty five I thought I was ten feet tall, bullet proof and immortal. If someone told me back then I would be sixty two years old and have a wealth of health issues I’d have told you that you were nuts.
Yes, I guess because most people just take one day at of time and not think and some just work and pay bills, and some don't do anything at all and maybe just need to take a breath of air and relax.
Some do by not using it to their full potential and wasting it destroying their bodies and lives. Others appreciate it and do what makes them happy.
Don’t take life too seriously, you’ll never get out alive anyway
